  • interval_throughput –

  • csv –

  • throughput_graph –

  • file_name (str) – pcap file for analysis

  • client (str) – address ip with port for filtering

  • server (str) – address ip with port for filtering

Returns

list of timestamp and tuple (time,tcp payload size) from all filtered packets

graph.size_payload_graph(data, leg_x, leg_y, protocol)¶
Parameters

  • protocol – TCP or UDP

  • data (list[(x,y)]) – x timestamps that start the interval and y is number of packets for each interval

  • leg_x (str) – legend axe x

  • leg_y (str) – legend axe y

Returns

set of coordinates where x time and y tcp payload size (no return) and show graph

graph.throughput_graph(data, leg_x, leg_y, title)¶
Parameters

  • title – title of graph

  • data (list[(x,y)]) – x timestamps that start the interval and y is number of packets for each interval

  • leg_x (str) – legend axe x

  • leg_y (str) – legend axe y

Returns

plot graph and show the graph (with the cusum graph)

analysis_data.check_threshold(data, threshold)¶
Parameters

  • data – list of tuple (x,y) where x time and y packet/interval

  • threshold – filter value equal or over upper this threshold

Returns

list filter with the threshold

analysis_data.cusum(data)¶
Parameters

data –

Returns

cusum value for all data

analysis_data.cusum_calculation_lo(rate, mean, previous, variance)¶
Parameters

  • rate – rate from one sequence

  • mean – packet rate in mean to detect variation

  • previous – value cusum from the previous calculation

  • variance – to evalute the k for the tolerance

Returns

cusum value for the rate interval

analysis_data.cusum_calculation_up(rate, mean, previous, variance)¶
Parameters

  • rate – rate from one sequence

  • mean – packet rate in mean to detect variation

  • previous – value cusum from the previous calculation

  • variance – to evaluate the k for the tolerance

Returns

cusum value for the rate interval

  • array – [a,b,c]

  • value –

Returns

the index of an element of the table where whe have the closest element of value

analysis_data.get_interval(data, size, time, shift)¶
Parameters

  • data –

  • size – size of the (or the right) part of the subarray around the time value

  • time – value that we want the most close in our array to have a right and left part

  • shift – shift to the right from the array around the value

Returns

a subarray of data between arround the time value

analysis_data.smooth(data, coefficient)¶
Parameters

  • data – axe values that we want smooth

  • coefficient – if 3 then x 0 1 2

Returns

values smoothed

analysis_data.time_interval(second, timestamp)¶
Parameters

  • second (int) – size in second of the interval where we count the number of packets

  • timestamp (collection.iterable) – collection of all timestamp packets

Returns

list of tuple list(x,y) where x is time and y number packets per interval

tcp_payload –

Returns

bimodal_statistics.py¶

bimodal_statistics.difference_data(data, size, delay, alpha)¶
Parameters

  • data –

  • size – size of the right (or the left part of the array

  • delay – time in the second that are not take in account in the right part (to avoid irrelevant threshold during the transition

Returns

print p-value, mean, std and return True if the hypothesis nul is accepted

bimodal_statistics.getExtremePoints(data, typeOfInflexion=None, maxPoints=None)¶

This method returns the indices where there is a change in the trend of the input series. typeOfExtreme = None returns all extreme points, max only maximum values and min only min,

bimodal_statistics.my_kde_bandwidth(obj, fac=0.2)¶

We use Scott’s Rule, multiplied by a constant factor.
